channel.title: Wash Post Nation
channel.description: Check out Washington Post's National coverage. Get the latest national news,featuring national security,science and the courts. Read breaking national news headlines from across the US.

item.title: To N.Y. Muslims, Islamic center near Ground Zero would be more than a mosque
item.description:
This is what the controversial Islamic community center and mosque being planned in Lower Manhattan means to Ehab Zahriyeh: not having to play basketball in church leagues.

item.title: Prosecutors study jurors' remarks to media for keys to retrying Blagojevich
item.description:
As prosecutors began preparing Wednesday for the retrial of Rod Blagojevich on corruption charges, they wrestled with whether to retool a complex case that left some jurors confused and others unconvinced that the former Illinois governor had broken the law.


Rod Blagojevich - Barack Obama - Jury - United States - Federal Bureau of Investigation

item.title: As gulf cleanup continues, BP will also struggle to clean up its brand
item.description:
HOUSTON -- The protesters have stopped coming here to wave angry signs in front of BP's large office campus. The boycotts of BP gas stations are tapering off, too -- both signs that the energy company's plug of the spewing Gulf of Mexico oil well is quieting its loudest critics.


BP - Brand - Business - United States - Home
item.dc:creator: Krissah Thompson

item.title: Judge decries lenient treatment of banks but approves Barclays deal
item.description:
A federal judge Wednesday denounced the Obama administration's treatment of major global banks accused of violating U.S. laws, saying the government lets them off easy by declining criminal prosecution in exchange for payments of hundreds of millions of dollars.

item.title: Exercising new ability to spend on campaigns, Target finds itself a bull's-eye
item.description:
When Target gave money in July to a pro-business group in Minnesota, the company thought it was helping its bottom line by backing candidates in its home state who support lower taxes. Instead, the retailer has found itself in a fight with liberal and gay rights groups that has escalated into calls...

item.title: Poll shows more Americans think Obama is a Muslim
item.description:
The number of Americans who believe -- wrongly -- that President Obama is a Muslim has increased significantly since his inauguration and now account for nearly 20 percent of the nation's population.

item.description:
The interrogation of Ramzi Binalshibh , a key figure in the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, was recorded several times while he was being questioned in Morocco by local intelligence officers, according to a U.S. official. The disclosure resolves a mystery over what are thought to be the only existing...

item.title: Blagojevich is convicted of 1 of 24 counts; prosecutors vow retrial
item.description:
A federal jury in Chicago convicted former Illinois governor Rod Blagojevich of one count of lying to the FBI but deadlocked on 23 corruption counts Tuesday, a setback for prosecutors who spent years pursuing the voluble and theatrical Democrat.

item.description:
BEIJING -- A plane thought to be a military fighter jet crashed into a fruit field in northeastern China on Tuesday, and China's official state-run news agency said the aircraft may have come from North Korea.

item.title: Massey Energy cited for failing to report mine accidents
item.description:
Government investigators have cited Massey Energy for failing to report more than 20 accidents at its Upper Big Branch coal mine in the two years before an April explosion killed 29 miners there, according to documents released by the Mine Safety and Health Administration on Tuesday.

item.title: Gov. Paterson aims to broker relocation of Ground Zero mosque
item.description:
NEW YORK -- New York Gov. David Paterson (D) plans to meet later this week with the Islamic prayer leader and the developer of a planned mosque near Ground Zero to discuss the possibility of moving the controversial project to an alternate site, Rep. Peter King (R-N.Y.) said Tuesday.

item.title: Unallayed by tests, fishermen greet start of gulf shrimp harvest with suspicion
item.description:
On Monday, Louisiana's shrimpers could shrimp again. On the first day of the state's fall season, boats began unloading their catch at bayou-side docks, and processors began peeling, freezing and packaging the shellfish for the long trip to America's dinner plates.

item.title: Karzai wants private security firms out of Afghanistan
item.description:
KABUL -- American officials were stunned Monday by a surprise announcement from President Hamid Karzai's spokesman calling for the dissolution within four months of the private security companies that foreign armies and aid organizations in Afghanistan rely on to do their daily work.

item.title: Corrections
item.description:
-- An Aug. 11 Metro article about the start of Ramadan incorrectly said that the Muslim holiday, which is tied to the lunar calendar and thus changes every year, "will soon arrive in the fall," later than this year's summer dates. The month-long holiday will actually shift to earlier in the year.

item.title: Federal appeals court puts California gay marriages on hold
item.description:
California's ban on same-sex marriages will remain in place until at least December, an appeals court ruled Monday, dashing the hopes of hundreds of couples who had hoped to wed as soon as Wednesday.

item.description:

item.title: Minorities disproportionately discharged for 'don't ask, don't tell' violations
item.description:
The military threw out hundreds of service members in 2009 for violating its "don't ask, don't tell" policy, including a disproportionate number of women and minorities and dozens of service members in "mission critical" positions, according to a new analysis of military data.
